channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Advanced Perl Maven online video course
item.description: When I announced the course I offered a 81% discount for 3 days. I'd like to offer this discount to you, the reader of the Perl Weekly as well. Until the 15th December you'll be able to used the 'advanced_intro_9' coupon and get the advanced course for $9 instead of $49. The two parts of the Beginner course also have discount codes: 'beginner_15' and 'beginner2_15' respectively for $15 instead of $39 each.

item.title: The Triumphant Return of Zoidberg -- A Modular Perl Shell
item.description: Joel Berger announces a new version of the Perl shell. Cleaned and washed and ready to party.

item.title: Perl Rocks Latin America
item.description: Mark Keating (MDK) writes about the W3C competition and about the only Perl team that participated, and won. Leaving 46 other teams wishing they had better tools.

item.title: use B::Stats to check for less bloat
item.description: Reini Urban gives us a couple of examples where little, innocent looking modules eat up a lot of memory. He also point to tools to check memory footprint. Memory optimization might be an important field we have been neglecting in the Perl/CPAN community. Or maybe it's just me.

item.title: Create your own dualvars
item.description: In Perl each scalar variable has both a string value and a numerical value. Usually they are related. brian d foy shows how to create such variables using Scalar::Util.

item.title: rjbs versus Encode
item.description: It's always fascinating to see a fight between man and machine. This time it is Ricardo Signes (RJBS) had to deal with Encode, folding and Tibetian e-mail messages.

item.title: Track App Progress with Writable $0
item.description: chromatic explains how to change the name of your process as see by ps or top on Linux.

item.title: How to parse HTML, part 2
item.description: If you have been following the posts of Jeffrey Kegler, and I saw many people clicked on those links, then you might be interested in the second part of this article.

item.title: The Ten Minute Thinking Rule
item.description: I love the way Chisel explains how to get people to start thinking about a problem they face. It isn't always possible but I think it can work very well. Much better than saying RTFM or by giving them the solution.

item.title: Announcing MooseX::Types::NumUnit for scientific simulations
item.description: Joel Berger is doing scientific simulations so he needed complex types that understand things like ft/s (or m/s for those in the metric system).

item.title: Using system or exec safely on Windows
item.description: Graham Knop, who almost never uses Perl on Windows invested his time creating a way to escape all the characters that need to be escaped on Windows. This sound a lot simpler than it is. I wish someone packaged this solution and put it on CPAN.

item.title: YAPC::NA has a suggestion box that you can vote on
item.description: Usually I don't link to the small blog entries regarding next years YAPC::NA but this one I liked very much. This 'Mob Rater' let's you suggest ideas for YAPC::NA and vote on the other ideas listed. I think this is a nice idea and the results could be used by any YAPC or Perl workshop. So even if you don't plan to attend YAPC::NA I'd suggest you go put in your suggestions and vote on the other ones.

item.title: (vi) stackoverflow perl report
item.description: This weeks to 10 Perl on Stack Overflow got some very interesting links. Thanks to Miguel Prz (niceperl) for collecting them week after week.

item.title: Best Practical is looking for a Perl Hacker
item.description: This is the company of Jesse Vincent, the former Perl 5 Pumpkin
